Pentagon says ‘identity months’ like Black History Month are ‘dead’ Shortly after President Donald Trump signed a proclamation celebrating National Black History Month on Friday, the Pentagon issued guidance declaring that “identity months” were “dead” within the Defense Department. Trump’s proclamation acknowledged the contribution of several history-making Black Americans, calling upon “public officials, educators, librarians, and all the people of the United States to observe this month with appropriate programs, ceremonies, and activities.” But Friday’s guidance from Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth specifically states that the Pentagon will no longer “use official resources, to include man-hours, to host celebrations or events related to cultural awareness months, including National African American/Black History Month, Women’s History Month, Asian American and Pacific Islander Heritage Month, National Hispanic Heritage Month, National Disability Employment Awareness Month, and National American Indian Heritage Month.” The memo added though that employees, including service members in the military and civilians, could attend such events outside of their work time. “We are proud of our warriors and their history, but we will focus on the character of their service instead of their immutable characteristics,” the memo says.
